so I like that video because it talks from a student's point of view from the university's point of view from a
professor's point of view about the value of the kik there at the DX hub we talked in the video there were some of

challenges so how do we go about working on those challenges and that's where the Amazon innovation processes come in that
I'll talk about so innovation begins where we start with the customer and work backwards so working backwards is
usually a generic term there's a vision statement and you want to work backwards from it within Amazon the working
backwards process is a very specific methodology of what we do and when we come up with an idea where we think we
can delight and obsess over our customers we don't write code we don't write a prototype or build a prototype
first what we do is we write a press release we write a press release as if
the situation or the solution already exists what would we say about it what
would a customer say about it and then we work backwards from that vision so it's it's a mock press release sometimes
some of those wordings make it to the real press release but it has the look and feel of a real press release and the
idea it's a one-page narrative of our vision of why we want to do a new idea and so we work on developing a press
release for each of those challenges that you just saw and when you think about the innovations that Amazon has
with Prime echo 165 AWS services they all have their internal press release
before we actually build the product and so we start with the customer and we work backwards and we ask ourselves
these five questions every time who is the customer sometimes there's a lot of
customers a lot of stakeholders but we want to try to narrow it down to a customer a persona or maybe someone very
specific so that you can really delight that example like extreme example and
then what is the customer problem or opportunity what is it exactly that you're trying to solve and what is the
most important customer benefit and is it clear usually when you come up with an idea there may be 15 reasons why it's
a good idea but what's that most salient one if you write a press release maybe
the first paragraph is fully read well what would you say there so it's the oh wow factor of being able to want to try
or use this new service and then how do you know the customers want or need it what is the qualitative quantitative
data usually the first time you ask this question it's you're you're thinking about the plan or the type of data that
you need and then in the future you would actually provide that data it's so the working backwards process is a
living process and something we do iteratively and then what does the customer experience look like so walk us
through what a customer would do with this new solution or service and we do this for every innovation challenge and
so we write a press release there's some other documents I'll go through but
this is the engagement model of what we do for an innovation challenge throughout a cloud Innovation Center so
the first step we have is identify we want to figure out where's the customer
interest what are those problem areas solicit Innovation Challenge requests and then we engage with them we have we
introduced to our digital innovation model this particular engagement that I'm describing now and we frame the
design challenge what is it that we're trying to solve what is happening today what is the problem when they try to do
something and try to make it succinct and actionable for us to work on and that way we can figure out the right
people that we want to have in our innovation workshops which we have is our defined stage and the Amazon
innovation workshop is essentially going through a series of activities some of the Design Thinking some of its
brainstorming and group consensus it's one to two days of deep intensive
collaboration and the idea is to come up with the big idea to solve a particular problem set that you've defined and
framed the design challenge and then the output of that is drafting that first press release
now the second document in the working backwards process is the frequently asked questions document so the press
release is the vision of why you want to do something the FAQ is we have two of
them a customer FAQ and a stakeholder FAQ and that is the how are we going to
do it and what would it take so the customer FAQ talks about specifically
what would a customer say about your new solution what would their you know how much does it cost how do I use it what
would I use it for and a stakeholder FAQ would be what are the tools you need what are the resources you need when do
you plan on launching it what would the customer most liked about your solution what would a customer least liked about
your solution on the first version and then we go through the prototyping where
we iterate on the press release on the FAQ we look at the state of art in terms of alternative analysis and then we
clearly define the value proposition and we create proof of concepts or demos of
what we think could solve that problem and then we develop recommendations and we have an executive reviewed
we review these documents so when we announce Kendall for instance or an AWS
service we read the press release we read the FAQ s and we read various
visualizations that we do as well that's the third is the visual stations and storyboarding and then realize value in
terms of how are we going to and this is where we hand off to either partners or
to the customer themselves on how to take that idea to the next level and establishing an operating model if we
think that experiment is successful and then we do this multiple times or iterate across for the various
challenges so in summary these are the three main documents a press release the
frequently asked questions and the visuals and prototype and so this is a
